I come from Poland and I am a programist. I understand Bugzilla is a site to report bugs and I am sorry I boder you but I couldnt find any other way to send you any information with my advise. I am sure you have a lot of specialist who may have better concepts for Firefox on future but I hope it is good to try.
So what is on my mind? During last few years when I was working as web developer I've meet with significant problem around rich-text-widget.
When developers create advanced pages they have to programm widgets or use already prepared widgets like TinyMCE. The problem is it is a lot of work to create this kind of program or very expensive to buy ready to use widgets. I think this kind of widget should be build in the browser. To use it developer should write special HTML mark (exp. <richtext></richtext>) and use fully functional rich textbox.
Advantages? - More users using your browser (especially developers, admins, moderators, redactors). - You will be the first who will introduce very importand extension in next generation of browsers. - Most of technologies need few years to become a standard. But maybe in next few years other browsers will fallow your way. Disadvantage? - Incompatible with W3C. - At the beginning it will be working on your browser only.
Why I think it is worth to do even this 2 disadvantages? Advanced pages are made of 2 parts - frontend and backand. Frontend is this part of web site avalable for whole of the world. Backend is a place to manage the frontend. Many users use different browsers so thats why frontend should be working the same on all browsers. But it doesn't have to be like this with backend. Backend is a manager avalable just for a group of users like developers, admins, moderators etc. And this part of web site can have a requirement to use a special browser like Firefox. I think a lot of users will choose youre browser instead of others because of this feature. This widget will make life easier for developers and can become a standart of HTML in the future.
Reproducible: Always
